awd_titl_txt: Center for Quantum Information and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information science (QIS) is the interdisciplinary field that investigates how to use systems obeying the laws of quantum mechanics to perform information-processing tasks that cannot be performed efficiently using conventional information-processing systems.  This project funds center-wide research and outreach activities of the Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC). The Center involves the efforts of four faculty members at the University of New Mexico (UNM) and one at the University of Arizona (UA).   The goal of research at CQuIC is to combine the abstract understanding of QIS that comes from mathematical physics and computer science with the practical knowledge of physical systems that comes from physics, in order to design practical quantum-information-processing protocols and to implement such protocols in laboratories at UNM and UA.  

CQuIC's chief scientific-outreach activity is the administration and organization of the SQuInT Network, a consortium of 26 node institutions, including research universities, undergraduate colleges, national and industrial laboratories, and international centers for QIS research.  The SQuInT Annual Workshop, which had its seventeenth installment in February 2015, has grown to be one of the major scientific meetings in QIS, unique in its integration of physics and information-science talks and its emphasis on presentations by a mix of senior personnel, postdocs, and students.  This project provides partial, but substantial support for the SQuInT Annual Workshop.  

The research to be carried out under this project has two different, but closely related focuses.    The first is development of fundamental techniques for preparation of quantum states, control of quantum dynamics, and precision measurement, together with verification of any of these three. Some of the proposed research is theoretical and platform independent: Investigate in-situ characterization of errors in quantum information processing (QIP) protocols using syndrome data from quantum error correction. Other research is tightly coupled theory-experiment development and refinement of control toolkits for particular quantum systems, in this case, optical photons and cesium atomic ensembles:  Develop and implement sophisticated techniques for state, process, and detector (POVM) tomography in the 16-dimensional ground hyperfine manifold of the cesium atom, and develop and implement techniques to control and squeeze the collective spin of atomic ensembles consisting of a thousand to a million cesium atoms.  The second focus is application of these control techniques to QIP tasks.  Some of this work is primarily theoretical: Investigate the potential, capabilities, and robustness of analog quantum simulation, with particular attention to the prospects for boson sampling. Other research is tightly coupled theory-experiment application of control techniques to perform QIP tasks in our laboratory systems: Implement the quantum kicked top in the 16-dimensional ground manifold of cesium, and implement sophisticated techniques to discriminate optical-frequency coherent states for enhanced optical communication.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum information science (QIS) is the interdisciplinary field that investigates how to use systems obeying the laws of quantum mechanics to perform information-processing tasks.  This NSF award was the third center-wide grant to the Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC), which is based at the University of New Mexico (UNM), with an experimental-physics research node at the Optical Sciences Center of the University of Arizona (UA).  The award began on September 1, 2015, and ran through August 31, 2018.
Quantum mechanics is the framework within which the behavior of all physical systems is described, but the odd effects of quantum mechanics manifest themselves mainly in the behavior of systems at the atomic scale.  Larger systems, often called classical systems, tend to behave in ways that are consistent with what is called classical physics, which is a set of rules that are consistent with what we experience in our everyday lives.  Systems that behave according to the rules of quantum mechanics act quite differently from what we expect based on ordinary experience.
Research at CQuIC focuses on harnessing the new ideas and new techniques of QIS to the physics tasks of controlling the counter-intuitive behavior of quantum systems and measuring that behavior precisely to determine that the system has done what is desired and to detect external influences on the system.  Research under this award focused on two major questions: (i) Development of fundamental techniques for preparation of quantum states, manipulation and control of the evolution of quantum systems, and precision measurement, together with verification of any of these three; (ii) Application of the control techniques we develop to particular tasks for the processing of quantum information.   Specific outcomes on these research focuses include the following:
Quantum-state tomography (QST): Determining the state of a quantum system.  Theoretically optimal QST vs. real-world implementations.    We completed a comprehensive experimental study of QST protocols that compared theoretically optimal protocols with real-world protocols that were implemented in the laboratory.  Strictly-informationally-complete measurements for bounded-rank QST.  We studied the problem of QST under the assumption that the state is pure and, more generally, that its rank is bounded.   In this context, we found a new notion of informationally complete POVMs made possible by enforcing the constraint that quantum states must predict positive probabilities.
Efficient quantum process tomography (QPT) of near-unitary maps.  We implemented and tested a new protocol for QPT using an "intelligent probing" scheme developed at CQuIC under a previous NSF grant.
Quantum control and squeezing of collective atomic spins.  We conducted experiments that use backaction from a QND measurement to create entanglement and spin squeezing in an ensemble of approximately a million laser cooled and trapped cesium atoms.
Arbitrary Dicke-state control of symmetric Rydberg ensembles.  We showed that symmetric ensembles of neutral atoms interacting via the Rydberg blockade are well described by the Jaynes-Cummings Hamiltonian of cavity QED.
Optimized discrimination strategies for multistate discrimination beyond the quantum noise limit in the single-photon regime.  We developed and experimentally demonstrated optimized measurements for discrimination of multiple nonorthogonal coherent states.
Quantum thermodynamics from a quantum-information perspective.  We studied an autonomous quantum system that exhibits refrigeration under an information-work trade-off, much like a Maxwell demon.
Many-body entanglement as a resource for quantum computation.   We utilized recent advances in the subject of symmetry-protected topological order to introduce a novel resource state for measurement-based quantum computation.
Efficient classical simulation of quantum-optical experiments.  We established stringent conditions for efficient classical simulation of quantum-optical processes and applied these conditions to the boson-sampling problem, in which one samples from the photon-counting distribution at the output of a linear-optical network.
Measurement of the spin-coherent-state POVM by repeated weak measurements.   Overturning skepticism in much dof the community, we showed how to implement this POVM using repeated weak measurements of the three components of a spin's angular momentum.
Classical simulation of quantum circuits by dynamical localization.  We extended the concept of Anderson localization, the confinement of quantum information in a spatially irregular potential, to localization within quantum circuits.
Quantum limits on estimation of parameters of classical spacetimes.  Using techniques from local quantum field theory, we formulated a rigorous quantum Cramer-Rao lower bound for estimating the single parameter that varies in any one-parameter family of spacetime metrics
.
CQuIC is the administrative home for the Southwest Quantum Information and Technology (SQuInT) network, a consortium of research groups at roughly 30 institutions, located mainly in the US Southwest.  The main activity of the network is an Annual Workshop, a three-day conference held every February which places a premium on participation by and professional development of PhD students and postdoctoral fellows from the node institutions. During the lifetime of this award, CQuIC sponsored three Annual Workshops, in Albuquerque, Baton Rouge, and Santa Fe.  The Workshops were attended by between 150 and 225 researchers.
